It is extremely difficult to tell if something is a bubble or not in many cases.
The biggest signs of a bubble are when the price of production is not closely related to the price of the thing (i.e. the price of the thing is going up a lot faster than the cost of production is) or when the cost of a mundane good or service is going up much faster than salaries are. However, these sorts of things can be signs of other things (shortages, for instance).
Lots of market speculation is often a bad sign, as are things like low leverage.
I feel like it is a bubble because I don't see the prices as being reasonable, especially if interest rates go up, and because we're seeing a sharp increase in prices similar to what we saw back before the last one. But it is hard to say for sure that it is one.
It could also be a shortage, but there are problems there, too, as if the shortage is alleviated (by, say, building more high density housing within cities, or building more jobs outside of cities because cities are too expensive to do business in), that could result in the market plunging as well.
I feel like some places (Vancouver, BC) are clearly in the midst of a bubble, but other areas appear to be more or less a slow, steady increase rather than the spike. It is hard to say for sure, of course; there's people who make big bucks by anticipating a bubble bursting.

See: all the deaths for cannabis: 0
Protip: it is trivial to use Google to find out that this is false. The only people who make this claim are, I'm afraid, potheads.
First off, it is indeed possible to die from consumption of cannabis/THC; while for a long time there weren't any reported deaths as a result of such, in recent years they've become much more common (though still rare). About a score of deaths are reported per year now as a result of consumption of products containing THC and having a bad medical reaction, with a higher number (somewhat north of 100) recorded as a result of mixing marijuana with other substances, primarily alcohol (as marijuana and alcohol can have certain cumulative effects). AFAIK, all of the deaths from THC alone have involved extracts and edibles rather than smoked marijuana; it would be very difficult to smoke a lethal dose of THC (it would take hundreds of joints within a very short period of time). You'd probably die of other causes related to smoke inhalation before you died from the THC if you tried to smoke that much pot.
But people do nevertheless die. [Here's a paper from 2014 documenting two such deaths.](http://www.fsijournal.org/article/S0379-0738(14)00054-1/abstract)
A secondary cause is erratic behavior caused by consumption of cannabis. One of the more common side effects is anxiety, and there are recorded deaths ([such as this one](https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6428a6.htm)) which were caused by people's erratic behavior after consuming cannabis or THC. There's evidence that THC can trigger or worsen psychological disturbances, and as such, so any deaths resulting from such would be in part attributable to the consumption of THC.
Consumption of cannabis/THC is also associated with criminal behavior in much the same way as alcohol is; this isn't terribly surprising if you think about it, as both impair judgement. People who commit crimes are disproportionately likely to be under the influence of cannabis relative to the general population, indicating that at least some deaths as a result of crime have THC as a contributing factor.
Thirdly, there's accidental deaths. Cannabis is second to only alcohol in terms of appearance in fatal car crash victims. While some studies have claimed that this is due to the age of the victims, this is somewhat problematic because the causation can run the other way - i.e. younger drivers are more likely to get in crashes *because* they're more likely to abuse cannabis, and thus some of the risk factor from being a young driver is actually not from being young, but from more young people abusing cannabis. Studies have found that cannabis does significantly impair driving, and for longer than alcohol, though the acute impact is smaller (i.e. you are a worse driver for longer, but it impairs driving ability by less). It has also been found that mixing alcohol and cannabis results in greater impairment than would be expected by naive addition of their effects.
Fourth, the long-term health effects of marijuana are not well-known, but it probably kills a lot of people in the long run. No one has ever died from a nicotine overdose from a cigarette, but hundreds of thousand of people die premature deaths as a result of the long-term health effects of smoking each year. The same is true of alcohol consumption as well - the number of deaths from the immediate effects of alcohol are dwarfed by the deaths in the long term. There's no reason to believe that marijuana is any less toxic in the long term than smoking tobacco or drinking; it is known to cause brain damage in its heaviest users, something alcohol does, and inhaling smoke is certainly not good for your lungs. It may cause other forms of organ damage as well, given it can alter bloodflow to the organs and that it is a toxic substance which the body has to metabolize. Professor John Henry has estimated that the long-term health effects of cannabis consumption in the UK kill about 30,000 people per year, or about a quarter as many people as die from smoking tobacco.
It is hard to know how accurate these figures are, though; unfortunately, a lot of marijuana users also use other drugs (particularly tobacco and alcohol), which makes it more difficult to disentangle the health effects of cannabis consumption from those of other drugs. Additionally, as marijuana is an illegal drug, its usage is more difficult to track.
However, it is highly probable that the long term negative health effects of marijuana kill a lot of people each year.
Of course, there are things beyond deaths to consider; side effects are another major area of concern, and cannabis has serious side effects from the point of view of medical usage, impairing ordinary function.
